channel.title: Nature Now
channel.itunes:author: KPTZ's Nature Now Team
channel.description: Nature Now presents eclectic Pacific Northwest-focused news, insights and observations about the natural world around us. Anything that grabs the attention of the Nature Now team can be heard on these episodes: birds and bees, flowers and trees, the weather and the stars – everything from microscopic Salish Sea plankton to ecosystem dynamics in a changing world. Every member of the Nature Now team is fascinated by the wonders of the natural world around us, is endlessly curious, hungry for new knowledge, and loves to share these passions with our listeners.

item.title: Dune Restoration (Part 2)
item.itunes:title: Dune Restoration (Part 2)
item.itunes:summary: Debaran Kelso continues her conversation with Dr. Fred Sharpe about dune restoration and ecology on a field trip to Fort Worden State Park.
item.description:
Debaran Kelso continues her conversation with Dr. Fred Sharpe about dune restoration and ecology on a field trip to Fort Worden State Park (part 2 of a two part program). (Airdate: July 13, 2022)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Dune Restoration (Part 1)
item.itunes:title: Dune Restoration (Part 1)
item.itunes:summary: Join Debaran Kelso on a field trip to the sandy shores of Fort Worden with Dr. Fred Sharpe to speak about dune restoration.
item.description:
Join host Debaran Kelso on a field trip to the sandy shores of Fort Worden. Dr. Fred Sharpe is our guest to speak about dune restoration in this area and in other locations on the Olympic Peninsula (part 1 of a two part program). (Airdate: June 13, 2022)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Tree Thieves
item.itunes:title: Tree Thieves
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Lyndsie Bourgon, author of a new book on the subject of timber poaching.
item.description:
If you go into the woods at night, you better go in disguise… What? Tree thieves? It’s a bigger problem than you thought – threats to forest health and ecology, crime and survival, social and community failures, challenges for us all to do things differently. Nan Evans talks with Lyndsie Bourgon, author of a new book on the subject of timber poaching. (Airdate: June 8, 2022)

Learn more about Lyndsie Bourgon.

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Winter Weather, Summer Water
item.itunes:title: Winter Weather, Summer Water
item.itunes:summary: Ann Soule, Water Resource Manager, joins Mary Robson to evaluate what’s known about these strange cold weeks, current snowpack, and suggestions for managing during limited rain months.
item.description:
Rains will cease and summer’s coming, with predictable challenges to local water supplies. Ann Soule, Water Resource Manager for the city of Sequim, joins Mary Robson to evaluate what’s known about these strange cold weeks, current snowpack, and suggestions for managing during limited rain months. She’s watched that snowpack for over twenty years. (Airdate: May 18, 2022)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Climate Resiliency on the Olympic Peninsula (Part 2)
item.itunes:title: Climate Resiliency on the Olympic Peninsula (Part 2)
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans and Erik Kingfisher of the Jefferson Land Trust talk about climate resiliency on the north Olympic Peninsula.
item.description:
Nan Evans and Erik Kingfisher of the Jefferson Land Trust talk about climate resiliency on the north Olympic Peninsula. Longer, drier summers and warmer, wetter winters pose broad threats to the forests, farms, and wildlife habitats. Together Nan and Eric will explore whether current conservation efforts enough? Are these efforts strategically targeted to help benefit biological and human communities? How does science guide us in taking wise conservation actions for the future? Part 2 of a two part program. (Airdate: May 25, 2022)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Finding Port Orford Cedars at Fort Worden
item.itunes:title: Finding Port Orford Cedars at Fort Worden
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Maggie Baker and Suzy Elbow, this year’s AmeriCorps Service Members who are sponsored by the Friends of Fort Worden.
item.description:
Nan Evans talks with Maggie Baker and Suzy Elbow, this year’s AmeriCorps Service Members who are sponsored by the Friends of Fort Worden. Learn about their care of the parks natural resources, their public education activities, and about the Port Orford Cedars found up near the bunkers this past year. (Airdate: March 23, 2022)

item.title: We are Puget Sound (Part 2)
item.itunes:title: We are Puget Sound (Part 2)
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Mindy Roberts of the WA Environmental Council about the “We are Puget Sound” project – book, exhibits, and lectures.
item.description:
Nan Evans continues talking with Mindy Roberts of the Washington Environmental Council about the “We are Puget Sound” project – book, exhibits, and lectures. The “We are Puget Sound” campaign engages the people living in the Salish Sea watershed in loving, stewarding and enjoying the natural and human world around us (part 2 of a two part program). (Airdate: February 9, 2022)

item.title: Winter Walk with Lichens
item.itunes:title: Winter Walk with Lichens
item.itunes:summary: Join Mary Robson and Dr. Katherine Glew, University of Washington, for a winter walk with lichens.
item.description:
Join Mary Robson and Dr. Katherine Glew, University of Washington, for a winter walk with lichens. Now that the snows of late 2021 have gone in many places on the Quimper Peninsula, explore the winter woods with an eye to the small living world on the barks of trees and covering the ground and rocks. (Reprise airdate: January 6, 2022)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Orcas: Shared Waters, Shared Home
item.itunes:title: Orcas: Shared Waters, Shared Home
item.itunes:summary: Seattle Times writer Lynda Mapes joins Nan Evans to talk about Lynda’s new book, Orca: Shared Waters, Shared Home.
item.description:
Seattle Times writer Lynda Mapes joins Nan Evans to talk about Lynda’s new book, Orca: Shared Waters, Shared Home. Listen in to explore these unique individuals who astound us with their intelligence, strong culture and family structures, elaborate communications skills, and playfulness. (Airdate: October 13, 2021)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Outings with Friends and Strangers in the Time of Covid
item.itunes:title: Outings with Friends and Strangers in the Time of Covid
item.itunes:summary: Being in nature is keeping many of us sane during these Covid times - how shall we navigate the dilemma of enjoying and exploring nature with others during a pandemic?
item.description:
Being in nature is keeping many of us sane during these Covid times – being out-of-doors by ourselves, with friends or family, and with other naturalists. But, it is harder to feel comfortable on natural history outings. What are some of our local organizations doing to help us all stay safe? And, how shall we navigate the dilemma of enjoying and exploring nature with others during a pandemic? (Airdate: September 22, 2021)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Nature Obscura (Part 2)
item.itunes:title: Nature Obscura (Part 2)
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Seattle author, photographer, and urban naturalist, Kelly Brenner, about her book Nature Obscura.
item.description:
Explore everything from flies to folklore as Nan Evans talks with Seattle author, photographer, and urban naturalist, Kelly Brenner, about her book Nature Obscura. (Airdate: July 7, 2021)

Learn more about Kelly Brenner.

item.title: Nature Obscura (Part 1)
item.itunes:title: Nature Obscura (Part 1)
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Seattle author, photographer, and urban naturalist, Kelly Brenner, about her book Nature Obscura.
item.description:
Nan Evans talks with Seattle author, photographer, and urban naturalist, Kelly Brenner, about her book Nature Obscura and the strange and wonderful things one can learn just by observing the world around us. Tardigrades? Slime molds? And who knows what else? (Airdate: May 12, 2021)

Learn more about Kelly Brenner.

item.title: Springtime in the Quimper Corridor
item.itunes:title: Springtime in the Quimper Corridor
item.itunes:summary: Celebrate the Quimper Wildlife Corridor with Nan Evans and her guests.
item.description:
Celebrate Port Townsend’s natural treasure, the Quimper Wildlife Corridor, with Nan Evans. Nan and her guests take listeners on a virtual field trip looking for the first signs of spring. Special guests are Sarah Spaeth, Director of Conservation and Strategic Partnerships with the Jefferson Land Trust, and local naturalists Wendy Feltham, Geoff Hammerson, and Chloe Lampert. (Airdate: April 7, 2021)

Learn more about the Quimper Wildlife Corridor.

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Puffins and Climate Change
item.itunes:title: Puffins and Climate Change
item.itunes:summary: What can puffins tell us about the impact of climate change on marine ecosystems?
item.description:
Climate change in the marine environment, food webs and forage fish, puffins and other seabirds – fitting it all together. Nan Evans, in conversation with Dr. John Piatt of the USGS Alaska Science Center, explores the interconnections and the changing marine ecosystems. (Airdate: March 10, 2021)

Watch Dr. Piatt's lecture: What Can Puffins Tell Us about the Impact of Climate Change on Marine Ecosystems?.

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Being a Naturalist in the Year of the Pandemic
item.itunes:title: Being a Naturalist in the Year of the Pandemic
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans and Wendy Feltham talk about their experiences as naturalists during this strange last year of the pandemic.
item.description:
Nan Evans and Wendy Feltham talk about their experiences as naturalists during this strange last year of the pandemic – adjusting to stay-at-home orders, practicing social distancing, losing opportunities, discovering new ways of learning and sharing, finding new favorite places to explore in our own neighborhoods, and adapting to change. (Airdate: March 3, 2021)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!

item.title: Coastal Habitat Restoration
item.itunes:title: Coastal Habitat Restoration
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with Dr. Ron Thom about coastal and estuarine ecosystem restoration and the concept and science of net habitat improvement.
item.description:
Nan Evans talks with Dr. Ron Thom, Staff Scientist Emeritus with the Pacific Northwest National Lab in Sequim, about coastal and estuarine ecosystem restoration and the concept and science of net habitat improvement. (Airdate: January 6, 2021)

Watch Dr. Thom's lecture: What Eelgrass and Other Marine Vegetation Can Tell Us About the Future of Oceans.

item.title: What is a Naturalist?
item.itunes:title: What is a Naturalist?
item.itunes:summary: Nan Evans talks with local naturalist Ken Wilson about observing the world around us as a naturalist and Ken’s belief that we as humans, are innately, naturally, neurologically, and genetically wired to be naturalists.
item.description:
Nan Evans talks with local naturalist Ken Wilson about observing the world around us as a naturalist and Ken’s belief that we as humans, are innately, naturally, neurologically, and genetically wired to be naturalists. We can be fascinated and often excited by observing behaviors, attributes and traits in the natural world – using our sensory experiences in the noticing of patterns and variety in the world around us. (Airdate: June 4, 2020)

Nature Now is created by a dedicated team of volunteers. If you enjoy this episode and want to support the work that goes into making Nature Now, we invite you to go to kptz.org/donate to make a contribution. Thank you for your support!
